source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Studies of uniform oxide growth have concentrated on understanding Zircaloy-4 performance in PWRs.

extra_properties.optimization_criteria: A parameter > 10⁻¹⁷ h for improved corrosion resistance
extra_properties.cooling_rate_effect: Rapid cooling requires more annealing for matrix depletion

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Kilp also summarized their efforts to optimize Zircaloy-4 chemistry.

extra_properties.chemistry_controls: tighter controls on [C], [N] (lower values) and [Si] (higher values) within ASTM B353 range

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Garzarolli et al. [25] studied the effects of various chemical additions to autoclave water.
corrosion_data: moderate effects from most additives, decreased time to transition

extra_properties.additives_tested: chromate, nitrate, Cr₂O₃, NiFe₂O₃, NiO, SiO₂, Fe₃O₄
extra_properties.H₃BO₃_effect: significantly slower corrosion rate when combined with LiOH

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk4
evidence_span: Schematic of oxidation processes in zirconium alloys

extra_properties.corrosion_mechanism: atomic hydrogen production location determines nodule formation susceptibility

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Cheng and Adamson [53] annealed samples of sponge-grade Zr, of sponge-grade Zr metallurgically bonded to Zircaloy-2, and of crystal-bar-grade Zr metallurgically bonded to Zircaloy-2 at 900°C for various lengths of time between 1 and 120 min

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: sponge-grade Zr metallurgically bonded to Zircaloy-2 showed dramatic improvement in nodular corrosion resistance with up to 10 min annealing time
test_type: autoclave corrosion testing, metallography, SIMS analysis
corrosion_data: dramatic improvement in nodular corrosion resistance with up to 10 min annealing, slow degradation with longer annealing

extra_properties.corrosion_resistance: improved with up to 10 min annealing
extra_properties.solute_diffusion: Ni and Fe concentrations increased in matrix after 1 min at 900°C
extra_properties.precipitate_behavior: precipitates in Zircaloy-2 dissolved and alloying elements diffused into Zr

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: crystal-bar Zr bonded to Zircaloy-2 showed dramatic improvement in nodular corrosion resistance with up to 10 min annealing time
corrosion_data: dramatic improvement in nodular corrosion resistance with up to 10 min annealing, slow degradation with longer annealing

extra_properties.corrosion_resistance: improved with up to 10 min annealing

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: annealing Zircaloy-2 up to 48 h at 760°C resulted in improved rather than degraded nodular corrosion resistance
test_type: corrosion testing, precipitate distribution and chemical composition analysis

extra_properties.precipitate_changes: Zr₂(Ni,Fe) decreased in Ni/Cr ratio by up to 60%
extra_properties.solute_diffusion: Ni diffused into matrix, Ni diffused much faster than Fe

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Bibb and Fascia corroded single crystals of crystal-bar zirconium wafers in 360°C 18.6 MPa water. They reported differences in transition thickness but not in pretransition oxidation rate for eight orientations. Transition time ranged from 114 days for (1014) to 325 days for (2130).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk6
evidence_span: Charquet et al. [58] studied large-grain Zircaloy-4 and correlated texture with corrosion resistance in 500°C EPY 10.3 MPa steam. They found samples with the basal poles highly oriented normal to the corroding surface had only one half the corrosion as samples that had basal poles less textured with the maximum concentration of basal poles at 30° to the normal to the corroding surface.
corrosion_data: 50% reduction with basal poles normal to surface

extra_properties.texture_effect: basal poles normal to surface show half the corrosion

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Charquet et al. also studied the effect of microstructure, specifically the effect of the Fe and Cr alloying elements. They used two different heat treatments to obtain large lamellar grains with the Fe and Cr, primarily in precipitates, absent from some grains.

extra_properties.microstructure: large lamellar grains with Fe and Cr precipitates
extra_properties.corrosion_behavior: nodules formed on grains without precipitates, thin oxide layers on grains with precipitates

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Perkins et al. [32] reported that Zr₂(Ni,Fe) was significantly more corrosion resistant than Zr(Fe,Cr)₂. In fact, after annealing 500°C for 24h, Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ was completely oxidized while Zr₂(Ni,Fe) was only slightly oxidized.

extra_properties.oxidation_resistance: Zr₂(Ni,Fe) significantly more corrosion resistant than Zr(Fe,Cr)₂

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Ploc [59] studied this mechanism in O₂-oxidized binary zirconium alloys by careful scanning electron microscopy and scanning Auger microprobe analysis.

extra_properties.corrosion_mechanism: local accelerated corrosion by partially oxidized Zr-Ni precipitates

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Trowse et al. [60] studied nodular corrosion on zirconium alloys, primarily Zircaloy-2, in the Steam-Generating Heavy-Water Reactor (SGHWR).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk7
evidence_span: Wadman and Andren [64] in their examination of Zircaloy-4 matrix composition with an atom probe field ion microscope. They found a correlation between matrix iron concentration and both out-of-pile corrosion resistance and heat treatment.

extra_properties.matrix_composition: correlation between iron concentration and corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Yang et al. [66] also reported that beta-quenched or alpha + beta-quenched Zircaloy-4 contained fine platelet Zr₄(Fe,Cr) precipitates along interlamellar boundaries. These precipitates dissolved during irradiation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk8
evidence_span: Chung examined Zircaloy2 and Zircaloy-4 from four BWRs and a PWR. He found partial amorphization of both Zr(Fe,Cr)₂ and Zr?(Fe,Ni) precipitates after neutron fluences of 3.3×10²¹ n/cm² (E > 0.1 MeV)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk8

conditions: ⁴⁰Ar⁺⁺ ions, PWR neutrons, 1 MeV electrons

extra_properties.amorphization_mechanism: distortion energy increase to amorphous structure level
extra_properties.diffusion_behavior: Fe and Cr diffusion into matrix at higher temperatures/longer durations

corrosion_data: high corrosion rate out of reactor

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk10

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk10
evidence_span: Corrosion in reactor or postirradiation, even with the in-pile oxide removed, was much less than that of unirradiated material

extra_properties.precipitation_behavior: irradiation resulted in additional precipitation of beta Nb in alpha grains

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Kilp et al. [34] reported results of both autoclave and in-reactor corrosion tests on three Zr-Nb binaries, including Zr-2.5Nb. Performance was good in autoclaves but one of the reactor cycles during in-pile testing had high coolant dissolved O₂ concentrations and Zr-1Nb rods developed locally thick oxides, which the authors referred to as nodules. The nodule thicknesses were 60 to 90 μm

extra_properties.corrosion_behavior: accelerated localized corrosion under high oxygen conditions

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Kilp's 773 K (500°C) steam test showed that nodules did not develop on Zr-2.5Nb

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Sabol et al. [7] reported that Zr-0.5Nb material had a low corrosion rate in autoclave tests until a weight gain of ≤50 mg/dm², after which the corrosion rate accelerated dramatically
corrosion_data: low corrosion rate until ≤50 mg/dm² weight gain, then dramatic acceleration

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Kilp et al. tested Zr-1Nb-1Sn-0.1Fe in both autoclaves and in BR-3. Their autoclave tests included LiOH concentration as a variable. They found this alloy, named ZIRLO™, to be much less sensitive to environmental variations than the Zr-Nb binaries
conditions: autoclave with LiOH concentration variations, BR-3 reactor
corrosion_data: much less sensitive to environmental variations

extra_properties.environmental_sensitivity: low sensitivity to LiOH concentrations and oxygen

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Glazkov et al. [35] and Grigoriev [47] found that Zr-1Nb-1Sn-0.5Fe was less sensitive to high dissolved O₂ concentrations than Zr-1Nb
corrosion_data: less sensitive to high dissolved O₂

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: They performed chemical microanalyses on Zr-1Nb and Zr-1Nb-1Sn-0.5Fe samples that had oxide films grown in 623 K (350°C) and 773 K (500°C) steam. Nb, Fe, Sn, and O were profiled by elemental scans

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk11
evidence_span: Fe and Nb were observed to be more homogeneous in Zr-1Nb-1Sn-0.5Fe after the autoclave treatment than in Zr-1Nb, especially in the low-temperature 623 K (350°C) long-time (9500 h) test

extra_properties.element_homogeneity: Fe and Nb more homogeneous after treatment

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk12
evidence_span: Garzarolli et al. [6] expressed the transition from uniform to nodular corrosion as occurring abruptly at a particular value of the annealing (A) parameter. Considering the environmental parameters temperature, coolant dissolved-oxygen concentration, and irradiation flux, which are known to affect susceptibility to nodular corrosion, a similar representation is provided in Fig. 3. Selected data that identify locations on this transition surface are shown in Fig. 4.
conditions: temperature, coolant dissolved-oxygen concentration, irradiation flux
corrosion_formula: transition occurs at particular value of annealing (A) parameter

extra_properties.environmental_parameters: temperature, coolant dissolved-oxygen concentration, irradiation flux

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk13
evidence_span: Increasing burnups, especially in high-duty PWRs, has promoted investigation into alternate zirconium alloys. Alloys with niobium additions have been most actively pursued, perhaps due to their successful use in USSR and CANDU reactors
corrosion_data: superior corrosion resistance due to posttransition behavior

extra_properties.corrosion_mechanism: oxide forms porosity at interface between pretransition and posttransition oxides, maintaining protective layer

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk13
evidence_span: Development of new alloys shows promise, as demonstrated by Kilp et al. for Zr-1Nb-1Sn-0.1Fe

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk16
evidence_span: N. Ramasubramanian' (written discussion)—Assuming substitutional solution of alloying additions in zirconium oxide, niobium (supervalent) might be expected to make the oxide semiconduction by $\mathrm { N b ^ { 4 + }  N b ^ { 5 + } }$ transition. In the case of iron. nickel, and possibly chromium (subvalent), an increase in anion vacancy concentration rather than the generation of free carriers, "holes," is expected.

extra_properties.semiconductor_mechanism: Nb⁴⁺/Nb⁵⁺ transition for supervalent, anion vacancy concentration for subvalent

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk16
evidence_span: Brian $C o x ^ { 2 }$ (written discussion)—There are a number of fallacies gaining wide acceptance in studies of zirconium-alloy corrosion. For the present discussion I mention only three: (1) In a coherent $\boldsymbol { Z } \boldsymbol { \mathrm { r O } } _ { 2 }$ film, alloying additions with free energies of formation of their oxides lower than that for Zr should only achieve their "normal" (that is. aqueous solution ionic state) valences at the oxide environment interface. Experimental evidence is now slowly becoming available to support this (iron is $\mathrm { F e ^ { 0 } }$ and niobium either $\mathrm { N b ^ { \mathrm { 0 } } }$ or $\mathrm { \Delta N b ^ { + 2 } }$ close to the metal oxide interface).

extra_properties.alloying_element_valence: iron as Fe⁰, niobium as Nb⁰ or Nb⁺² near metal-oxide interface
extra_properties.free_energy_consideration: alloying additions with lower oxide formation energy than Zr

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk16
evidence_span: (2) Experiments showing improved resistance of liners to nodular corrosion following high-temperature anneals do not support a hypothesis based on the alloying elements being in solution in the zirconium matrix. Sponge zirconium always has ${ \mathrm { Z r / F e } }$ intermetallics precipitated in it, as does most crystal-bar zirconium. Thus Fe solubility in $Z \mathbf { r }$ is always exceeded in the liner; the anneal is changing the frequency size and distribution of the precipitated intermetallics.

extra_properties.microstructure_change: anneal changes frequency, size and distribution of precipitated intermetallics

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk16
evidence_span: (3) A solvated $\mathrm { { O H ^ { - } } }$ is the same whether it comes for LiOH, NaOH, KOH, or $\mathrm { N H } _ { 4 } \mathrm { O H }$ . Clearly [OH] is not an important factor in enhanced corrosion in LiOH since the same effect is not seen with other alkalis. Similarly, a solvated $\mathbf { L i } ^ { + }$ is the same whether it comes from LiOH, $\mathrm { L i N O } _ { 3 }$ , or Li acetate, and so forth. Again, $\left[ \mathbf { L i } ^ { + } \right]$ cannot be important since only LiOH produces the effect. The only reasonable conclusion from this is that the concentration of undissociated LiOH in solution is the important variable.

extra_properties.corrosion_mechanism: undissociated LiOH concentration is key factor
extra_properties.conclusion: neither [OH⁻] nor [Li⁺] alone causes enhanced corrosion

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk17
evidence_span: The effect of fabrication parameters on the inner microfissure in the Zr-lined cladding tube has been investigated

extra_properties.microfissure_formation: dependent on Q-value and grain size
extra_properties.grain_size_effect: smaller grain size reduces inner fissures

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_004_chunk17
evidence_span: The zirconium liner design is very important, in which a layer of pure zirconium is metallurgically bonded to the Zircaloy-2 inner surface
